pages.name: Sawmill
pages.text: The structure is built from the following $(t:8 Steel Scaffolding Blocks, 4 Iron Sheetmetal Blocks, 6 Light Engineering Blocks, 2 Heavy Engineering Blocks, 4 Conveyor Belts, and A Redstone Engineering Block.)$(#007500)blocks$(). $(wool)($(#007500)Orange carpet$() in place of rolling belts)

The sawmill is a machine assembly which cuts wooden logs into more efficiently than other means. The machine operates in two stages by first stripping the bark of the log and then using a sawblade to cut the stripped log apart.

The machine is built as shown on the first page and formed by using an $(hammer) on the central sheetmetal block. $(br)Applying a redstone signal to the control panel at the front will stop the machine, this behavior can be inverted by use of the $(screwdriver).

pages.title: Secondary Outputs
pages.text: The first step of the process creates $(#007500)Tree Bark$(), and the second step creates $(#007500)Sawdust$(). Both are output through the port at the front of the machine, and both can then be processed into paper later on.

To be fully ready for processing, you will need to craft a sawblade and insert it into the slot on the back by right-clicking.$(br)Sneak and right-click to take the sawblade out again (but $(bold)do not$() attempt to do this while the sawmill is running).

The sawblade will be damaged while it's in use and may need to be replaced after a while. Running logs through the machine without a sawblade will create $(#007500)stripped logs$() that will not be cut apart. This process is much quicker than stripping them manually.$(br2)The sawmill is also capable of reclaiming planks from wood-derived blocks such as doors and bookshelves.
